S3.T1.caption: Table 1:  Summary of datasets used in  InternVideo2  pretraining process.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2:  End-to-end finetuning action recognition results (top-1 accuracy) on Kinetics, SomethingSomething, and Moments in Time.  †  denotes that the result is achieved with different resolutions or frame rates.
references:
Tab. 2 shows InternVideo2-6B obtains new state-of-the-art (SOTA) results on Kinetics (92.1%/91.9%/85.9% on K400/600/700, respectively), SthSthv2, MiT, ANet, and HACS with only 16 frames, while the previous SOTAs require larger resolution (224 vs. 576) or model ensemble. As for MiT in Table 2,
InternVideo2-6B exceeds the previous SOTA, CoCa-g, by a significant margin of 2.2% (51.2% vs. 49.0%).
Regarding the temporal-related actions in Table 2,
our InternVideo2-6B also surpasses MVD Wang et al. (2023b) on SSv2 (77.5% vs. 77.3%).
Moreover, our InternVideo2-6B showcases top performance on untrimmed video analysis, as indicated in Table 2,
with 95.9% on ActivityNet and 97.0% on HACS.
These results affirm our model’s superior capability for robustly identifying complex actions across varied scenes.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3:  Attentive probing recognition results (top-1 accuracy) on Kinetics-400/600/700, Moments in Time and Something-Something V2.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4:  Linear probing action recognition results (top-1 accuracy) on Kinetics-400, Something-Something V2, UCF-101 and HMDB-51.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5:  Zero-shot action recognition results (top-1 acc) on UCF, HMDB, MiTv1, SSv2-MC, and Charades.
references: Table 5 and 6 show InternVideo2 gets 72.7% / 71.7% / 64.2% on K400/600/700, respectively, outperforming others but VideoPrism on K400 (76.4%). On UCF Soomro et al. (2012), HMDB Kuehne et al. (2011), MiT Monfort et al. (2020), SSv2-MC, and Charades, InternVideo2 gives an cutting edges over others. The clear gap between VideoPrism and InternVideo2 on K400 may signify the importance of pretraining corpus in VideoPrism (311M videos with text and 36.1M of them are manually labeled) for K400 in zero-shot. Note that on the datasets of Kinetics, UCF101 and HMDB51, which have a distribution closer to the pre-training dataset used in stage1, the performance of Internvideo2-6B is slightly inferior to that of Internvideo2-1B. We suppose this is caused by Internvideo2-6B uses a more abundant pretraining dataset in stage2, leading to the forgetting of pretraining data in stage1.

S5.T6.caption: Table 6:  Zero-shot action recognition results on Kinetics.

S5.T7.caption: Table 7:  Finetuned temporal action localization results on THUMOS14  Idrees et al. ( 2017 ) , ActivityNet  Krishna et al. ( 2017 ) , HACS Segment  Zhao et al. ( 2019 )  and FineAction  Liu et al. ( 2022 ) . We report average mAP. “Flow” denotes the ensembling I3D flow feature. * denotes the result is achieved with Flow.
references: We evaluate models on four temporal action localization (TAL) datasets: THUMOS14 Idrees et al. (2017), ActivityNet Krishna et al. (2017), HACS Segment Zhao et al. (2019) and FineAction Liu et al. (2022) in a feature-based manner with finetuning. We employ output of the 7-th layer from InternVideo2 for inputs as the corresponding features without fusing anything else. ActionFormer Zhang et al. (2022) is used as the detection head. We report mean Average Precision(mAP) under multiple tIoU as in Lin et al. (2019); Chen et al. (2022b); Zhang et al. (2022); Yang et al. (2023). In Table 7, InternVideo2-6B gets the highest mAP among all comparisons in all datasets, while InternVideo2-1B nearly surpass other methods except in THUMOS14. We find InternVideo2-6B almost consistently improves mAP with a notable margin from InternVideo2-1B except in FineAction. We suppose scaling model capacity without data refinement cannot nontrivially improve fine-grained discrimination abilities of models. Scaling detailed annotations in training may address this issue.

S5.T8.caption: Table 8:  Video instance segmentation performance (mAP) on YouTube-VIS19  Yang et al. ( 2019 ) .
references: We evaluate on the popular Video Instance Segmentation (VIS) dataset, Youtube-VIS 2019 Yang et al. (2019). Built upon Mask2Former Cheng et al. (2021), we employ the video encoder of InternVideo2 as backbone with ViT-adapter Chen et al. (2022c) for features. We also try InternViT Chen et al. (2023a) for comparisons. In Table 8, InternVideo2 gets the highest mAP among all. It improves mAP with a nontrivial margin over InternViT and Swin-L. This validates its effectiveness in relatively fine-grained spatiotemporal perception.

S5.T9.caption: Table 9:  Results of zero-shot video retrieval in both text-to-video (T2V) and video-to-text (V2T) on MSR-VTT, LSMDC, DiDeMo, MSVD, ActivityNet (ANet), and VATEX.
references: Table 9 and 10 demonstrate that InternVideo2 outperforms other state-of-the-arts with a notable margin in both t2v and v2t of all used datasets no matter in zero-shot or finetuned settings, except for the v2t of MSR-VTT, where VideoPrism gives the best result. This shows the video-language semantic alignment of transferrity of InternVideo2.

S5.T10.caption: Table 10:  Results of finetuning video retrieval in both text-to-video (T2V) and video-to-text (V2T) on MSR-VTT, LSMDC, DiDeMo, MSVD, ActivityNet (ANet), and VATEX.

S5.T13.caption:
Table 13:  Finetuned temporal grounding on QVHighlight  Lei et al. ( 2021 )  and Charade-STA  Gao et al. ( 2017 ) .
 (a)  QVHighlight (b)  Charade-STA
references:
We evaluate InternVideo2 on two temporal grounding (VTG) datasets: Qvhighlight Lei et al. (2021) and Charade-STA Gao et al. (2017). The eval setting and used features are the same as in TAL.
We use CG-DETR Moon et al. (2023) as the grounding head.
We report R1@0.3, R1@0.5, R1@0.7, and mAP for moment retrieval as in Lei et al. (2021); Moon et al. (2023); Lin et al. (2023). Highlight Detection is evaluated in terms of "Very Good" mAP and HiT@1.
In Table 13(b), InternVideo2-1B and InternVideo2-6B bring gradual performance improvements compared to CLIP Radford et al. (2021b) and CLIP Radford et al. (2021b)+Slowfast Feichtenhofer et al. (2019). This suggests that a larger spatiotemporal model is more beneficial to short-term video semantic alignment capabilities.

S5.T13.st1.caption: (a)  QVHighlight

S5.T13.st2.caption: (b)  Charade-STA

A3.T24.caption: Table 24:  Effect of feature extracted from the last 7 layers.
references: In Tab. C.1.1, the most effective feature tends to be located within the last few layers of the video encoder. This observation aligns with the similarity between feature-based temporal tasks and linear probing classification, which is reasonable. We undertake comprehensive experiments to investigate the impact of features from various layers, as detailed in Table 24. The results reveal the best features appear between the last 5-th layer and 7-th layer.

A3.T26.caption: Table 26:  Performance of multimodal LLMs on different question types and scenes of MoVQA.
references:
We evaluate InternVideo2 on the MoVQA for movie understanding. It is a long-form movie question-answering datasetZhang et al. [2023b]. MoVQA assesses the diverse cognitive capabilities of multimodal systems by considering both video length and clue length, relying on multi-level temporal lengths (single-scene, multi-scene and full-scene).
There are six types of QAs, including information synopsis, temporal perception, spatial perception, causal reasoning, hypothetical reasoning and external knowledge.
We evaluate InternVideo2-6B in the form of open-ended QAs, and detailed results are shown on Table 26.
